page.title: 03DUDMASTON GROUNDS
page.content: The area around Dudmaston Hall is {"The Dingle".}It is a piece of landscaping by Walter Wood, similar to that of William Shenstone at his home in Halesowen. The land surrounding the Hall is grazed by sheep. While the majority of the{deciduous {trees (oak, beech, lime)}contribute to the ornamental effect, they are also part of this century's afforestation plans. They are the culmination of Geoffrey Wolryche's forestry plans between 1908 and 1969. A large number of the elm trees have been cut down due to the effects of Dutch elm disease. The{National Trust}are currently engaged in restoring the Mill Pool at the foot of the Dingle. The large {man-made lake,}built in 1834, used to supply water to the estate . It was 3 separate pools until linked in 1837.
